trans-unit.source: Provides a set of properties and methods that are used to manage cookies.
This class cannot be inherited.
The <xref:System.Net.Cookie> class is used by a client application to retrieve information about cookies that are received with HTTP responses.
The following cookie formats are supported during parsing of the HTTP response headers: the original Netscape specification, RFC 2109, and RFC 2965.
For a list of initial property values for an instance of <xref:System.Net.Cookie>, see the various <xref:System.Net.Cookie> constructors.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref> class.
The default constructor initializes all fields to their default values, using empty strings ("") for `name`, `value`, `path`, and `domain`.
Note that at least the <xref:System.Net.Cookie.Name%2A> property must be initialized before using an instance of the <xref:System.Net.Cookie> class.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref> class with a specified <xref href="System.Net.Cookie.Name"></xref> and <xref href="System.Net.Cookie.Value"></xref>.
The default for the `value` parameter uses the empty string ("").
The `value` parameter for a <xref:System.Net.Cookie> must not be a `null` reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).
The semicolon (";") and comma (",") characters are reserved and cannot be passed in the `value` parameter unless the string passed in the `value` parameter is enclosed in double quotes.

So the following example constructor would succeed, but when you try to add this <xref:System.Net.Cookie> to a <xref:System.Net.CookieContainer> instance with the <xref:System.Net.CookieContainer.Add(System.Net.Cookie)> or <xref:System.Net.CookieContainer.Add(System.Uri,System.Net.Cookie)> methods, the operation will fail and throw an exception:
However, the following constructor with these special characters escaped will create a <xref:System.Net.Cookie> that can be added to a <xref:System.Net.CookieContainer> instance:
The comma character is used as a delimiter between separate cookies on the same line.
The name of a <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref>.
The following characters must not be used inside name: equal sign, semicolon, comma, newline (\n), return (\r), tab (\t), and space character.
The dollar sign character ("$") cannot be the first character.
The value of a <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref>.
The following characters must not be used inside value: semicolon, comma.
The name parameter is `null`.
-or-
The name parameter is of zero length.
-or-
The name parameter contains an invalid character.
-or-
The value parameter is `null` .
-or -
The value parameter contains a string not enclosed in quotes that contains an invalid character.

Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref> class with a specified <xref href="System.Net.Cookie.Name"></xref>, <xref href="System.Net.Cookie.Value"></xref>, and <xref href="System.Net.Cookie.Path"></xref>.
The default for the `path` parameter uses the empty string ("").
The `value` parameter for a <xref:System.Net.Cookie> must not be a `null` reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).
The semicolon (";") and comma (",") characters are reserved and cannot be passed in the `value` parameter unless the string passed in the `value` parameter is enclosed in double quotes.

So the following example constructor would succeed, but when you try to add this <xref:System.Net.Cookie> to a <xref:System.Net.CookieContainer> instance with the <xref:System.Net.CookieContainer.Add(System.Net.Cookie)> or <xref:System.Net.CookieContainer.Add(System.Uri,System.Net.Cookie)> methods, the operation will fail and throw an exception:
However, the following constructor with these special characters escaped will create a <xref:System.Net.Cookie> that can be added to a <xref:System.Net.CookieContainer> instance:
The comma character is used as a delimiter between separate cookies on the same line.
The name of a <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref>.
The following characters must not be used inside name: equal sign, semicolon, comma, newline (\n), return (\r), tab (\t), and space character.
The dollar sign character ("$") cannot be the first character.
The value of a <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref>.
The following characters must not be used inside value: semicolon, comma.
The subset of URIs on the origin server to which this <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref> applies.
The default value is "/".
The name parameter is `null`.
-or-
The name parameter is of zero length.
-or-
The name parameter contains an invalid character.
-or-
The value parameter is `null` .
-or -
The value parameter contains a string not enclosed in quotes that contains an invalid character.

Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref> class with a specified <xref href="System.Net.Cookie.Name"></xref>, <xref href="System.Net.Cookie.Value"></xref>, <xref href="System.Net.Cookie.Path"></xref>, and <xref href="System.Net.Cookie.Domain"></xref>.
The default for the `domain` and `path` parameters uses the empty string ("").
The `value` parameter for a <xref:System.Net.Cookie> must not be a `null` reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).
The semicolon (";") and comma (",") characters are reserved and cannot be passed in the `value` parameter unless the string passed in the `value` parameter is enclosed in double quotes.

So the following example constructor would succeed, but when you try to add this <xref:System.Net.Cookie> to a <xref:System.Net.CookieContainer> instance with the <xref:System.Net.CookieContainer.Add(System.Net.Cookie)> or <xref:System.Net.CookieContainer.Add(System.Uri,System.Net.Cookie)> methods, the operation will fail and throw an exception:
However, the following constructor with these special characters escaped will create a <xref:System.Net.Cookie> that can be added to a <xref:System.Net.CookieContainer> instance:
The comma character is used as a delimiter between separate cookies on the same line.
The name of a <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref>.
The following characters must not be used inside name: equal sign, semicolon, comma, newline (\n), return (\r), tab (\t), and space character.
The dollar sign character ("$") cannot be the first character.
The value of a <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref> object.
The following characters must not be used inside value: semicolon, comma.
The subset of URIs on the origin server to which this <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref> applies.
The default value is "/".
The optional internet domain for which this <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref> is valid.
The default value is the host this <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref> has been received from.
The name parameter is `null`.
-or-
The name parameter is of zero length.
-or-
The name parameter contains an invalid character.
-or-
The value parameter is `null` .
-or -
The value parameter contains a string not enclosed in quotes that contains an invalid character.
Gets or sets a comment that the server can add to a <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref>.
The client can inspect this optional comment for information added by the server.
For example, the server could include information about issues like the privacy policy or intended usage.
An optional comment to document intended usage for this <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref>.
Gets or sets a URI comment that the server can provide with a <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref>.
The URI can provide optional information, such as how the server uses the <xref:System.Net.Cookie>.
An optional comment that represents the intended usage of the URI reference for this <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref>.
The value must conform to URI format.
Gets or sets the discard flag set by the server.
When `true`, this property instructs the client application not to save the <xref:System.Net.Cookie> on the user's hard disk when a session ends.
`true` if the client is to discard the <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref> at the end of the current session; otherwise, `false`.
The default is `false`.
Gets or sets the URI for which the <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref> is valid.
A server cannot indicate a domain other than its own URI.
However, it can indicate more than one server in the domain.
The default value is the host that this cookie has been received from.
The URI for which the <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref> is valid.
Overrides the <xref href="System.Object.Equals(System.Object)"></xref> method.
A reference to a <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref>.
Returns `true` if the is equal to comparand.

Two <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref> instances are equal if their <xref href="System.Net.Cookie.Name"></xref>, <xref href="System.Net.Cookie.Value"></xref>, <xref href="System.Net.Cookie.Path"></xref>, <xref href="System.Net.Cookie.Domain"></xref>, and <xref href="System.Net.Cookie.Version"></xref> properties are equal.
<xref href="System.Net.Cookie.Name"></xref> and <xref href="System.Net.Cookie.Domain"></xref> string comparisons are case-insensitive.
Gets or sets the current state of the <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref>.
Expired cookies, if received, should be destroyed by the client application.
`true` if the <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref> has expired; otherwise, `false`.
The default is `false`.
Gets or sets the expiration date and time for the <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref> as a <xref href="System.DateTime"></xref>.
Setting the <xref:System.Net.Cookie.Expires%2A> property to <xref:System.DateTime> makes this a session <xref:System.Net.Cookie>, which is its default value.
The <xref:System.DateTimeKind> property of <xref:System.Net.Cookie.Expires%2A> is used to determine if the <xref:System.Net.Cookie> is set in <xref:System.DateTimeKind> or <xref:System.DateTimeKind>.
If the <xref:System.DateTimeKind> property is set to <xref:System.DateTimeKind>, then <xref:System.DateTimeKind> is assumed.
The expiration date and time for the <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref> as a <xref href="System.DateTime"></xref> instance.
Overrides the <xref href="System.Object.GetHashCode"></xref> method.
Classes that might be used as a key in a hash table must provide this override, because objects that are used as keys in a hash table are required to generate their own hash code through this method.
The 32-bit signed integer hash code for this instance.
Determines whether a page script or other active content can access this cookie.
When this property is set to `true`, a page script or other active content cannot access this cookie.
Boolean value that determines whether a page script or other active content can access this cookie.
Gets or sets the name for the <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref>.
The <xref:System.Net.Cookie.Name%2A> property must be initialized before using an instance of the <xref:System.Net.Cookie> class.
The following characters are reserved and cannot be used for this attribute value: equal sign, semicolon, comma, new line (\n), return (\r), tab (\t), and space character.
The dollar sign ($) character cannot be the first character.
The name for the <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref>.
The value specified for a set operation is `null` or the empty string
\- or -
The value specified for a set operation contained an illegal character.
The following characters must not be used inside the <xref href="System.Net.Cookie.Name"></xref> property: equal sign, semicolon, comma, newline (\n), return (\r), tab (\t), and space character.
The dollar sign character ("$") cannot be the first character.
Gets or sets the URIs to which the <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref> applies.
The <xref:System.Net.Cookie.Path%2A> property specifies the subset of URIs on the origin server to which this <xref:System.Net.Cookie> applies.
If this propery is not specified, then this <xref:System.Net.Cookie> will be sent to all pages on the origin server or servers.
The URIs to which the <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref> applies.
Gets or sets a list of TCP ports that the <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref> applies to.
This attribute restricts the ports to which this <xref:System.Net.Cookie> may be sent.
The default value means no restriction.
Setting this to the empty string ("") will restrict the port to the one used in the HTTP response.
Otherwise, the value must be a double-quoted string that contains port values delimited with commas.
The list of TCP ports that the <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref> applies to.
The value specified for a set operation could not be parsed or is not enclosed in double quotes.
Gets or sets the security level of a <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref>.
In effect, when this property is `true` this cookie may be sent only with https:// requests.
`true` if the client is only to return the cookie in subsequent requests if those requests use Secure Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTPS); otherwise, `false`.
The default is `false`.
Gets the time when the cookie was issued as a <xref href="System.DateTime"></xref>.
This is a read-only property.
The time when the cookie was issued as a <xref href="System.DateTime"></xref>.
Overrides the <xref href="System.Object.ToString"></xref> method.
The exact format of the string depends on the RFC that this cookie conforms to.
Returns a string representation of this <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref> object that is suitable for including in a HTTP Cookie: request header.
Gets or sets the <xref href="System.Net.Cookie.Value"></xref> for the <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref>.
The <xref:System.Net.Cookie.Value%2A> of a <xref:System.Net.Cookie> must not be `null`.
If a `null` value is assigned to this property, it's replaced with an empty string.
Semicolons and commas are reserved characters that cannot be used in the value of this property.

Assigning invalid characters to this property doesn't throw an exception; but when you try to add this <xref:System.Net.Cookie> to a <xref:System.Net.CookieContainer> instance with the <xref:System.Net.CookieContainer.Add%2A> method, the operation will fail and throw an exception.
The <xref href="System.Net.Cookie.Value"></xref> for the <xref href="System.Net.Cookie"></xref>.
Gets or sets the version of HTTP state maintenance to which the cookie conforms.
The default value for the <xref:System.Net.Cookie.Version%2A> property is 0, complying with the original Netscape specification.
If the value is explicitly set to 1, then this <xref:System.Net.Cookie> must conform to RFC 2109.
Note that if a <xref:System.Net.Cookie> was created automatically by receiving a Set-Cookie2 HTTP response header, the conformance is set to RFC 2965.
An attempt to set the <xref:System.Net.Cookie.Version%2A> property to a value less than zero will throw an exception.
The version of HTTP state maintenance to which the cookie conforms.
The value specified for a version is not allowed.
